Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 10:28PM mamasixtaz wrote: Yell, I so agree with what you are feeling.  It just becomes so overwhelming at times.  Your mind just can't cope with all the feelings going on inside.  When you run into people you haven't seen since dx, they all ask how's it going..you really want to say the truth, this really sucks! But you don't and say "I'm fine, how are you?"  No one wants to really know how you feel.  As soon as you say " I have breast cancer" it is a shock to everyone and then they don't know what to say.  I try to keep up a brave front at work and home for my family but at night it all comes crashing down.  It takes its toll on you, making me so tired yet still unable to sleep.  I wake up early unable to go back to sleep, which makes it so hard to keep up brave front. My good friend helps we work thru it by calling and texting frequently.  I feel better after talking to her.  Understand what you are going thru...hang in there.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2013 03:36PM mamasixtaz wrote: I was dx in Dec also before Christmas.  I did tell my familiy and a small group of close friends, including my boss.  I was so upset about the dx I could not absorb all the information myself let alone tell all.  It was also the holidays!  Who wants to hear bad news before Christmas?  I also wanted to find out more with all the tests MRIs, more biopsies,etc... I found out it was harder not to talk to people than it was to tell them what was going on with me.  It was hard to say "I have breast cancer" but after the first couple of times it became easier to say and handle the reactions.  I found it was then great to have the support of co-workers and learned how many more survivors had gone through this.  It is the most difficult thing to do but became my best support overall. It was so hard to wait until after Christmas and made the holidays very difficult.  If I had to do over would probably tell people sooner even if it does dampen the holiday.  I had some very intuitive staff that knew something was wrong but I wouldn't tell them, they really could tell something was up.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2013 03:06AM mamasixtaz wrote: Denilynne-Welcome to the September surgery thread, sorry you had to join us.  So sorry you are having such a bad time with your caregivers/providers.  You do have control over this.  I am a nurse and patient's let us know when they are not happy with care and we do listen.  Please continue to ask questions and search out a team you can feel cared for and listened to.  I have an HMO that isn't always easy to deal with but being a nurse I do stay persistent in getting answers and the care I need. Budget cuts, short staffing, limited office visits hinder the staff but do not make them so they can't show they care about you and your needs.  You are the pilot in this ship and you can guide it where it needs to go.  Stay in control of it and make them work for you.  Sometimes it takes more than one appt to get what you need but be persistant.  I learned this with my PS.  I was really upset after my first consultation that he only offered me LD flap reconstruction.  After researching this I was scared to death to go through so much surgery.  I called to talk to him and he was just so busy, so I made another appt to discuss this again.  I came prepared with all my questions and fears.  When I made the appt I asked for a longer appt time as I knew it could last past the normal 15 min slot. I made it at the end of the day.  We talked for about 45 min and he answered all my questions and understood how I was feeling.  He reassured me much more that everything would be ok, but it was in my court to decide what I wanted to do.  I felt soooo much better and empowered after that visit.  Made all the difference in the course of my care. I hope your lumpectomy and SNB goes well for you dispite the care you have (not) recieved. Wishing our first sugery sisters for September the very best...We will be thinking of you tomorrow as you put this surgery behind you.  Get some rest (LOL) if you can and take it easy after your surgery.  Please let us know how you are doing when you feel up to it.   September 3 -hobbesla4 (lumpectomy) DawnCT (lumpectomy) Sandymomof3(lumpectomy/SNB) Carrie61(UMX &SNB/reconTE) Fiddledeedee (Lumpectomy/SNB) Nicole21366 (mastectomy) September 4 Dennilynne-(lumpectomy/SNB)

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2013 03:31AM mamasixtaz wrote: Sandra-you have been through so much give yourself a break! Cry, rant, whine away, you deserve it.  It is such a long journey that none of us realize how our bodies are going to cooperate (or not)...Hopefully the antibiotics will be kicking butt and you will begin to feel better.  Necrosis and infections are the worst and set backs are just that set backs.  Time will move on and so will the healing. Take it one day at a time.  Feeling for you as I battled necrosis and incisional infections too but the antibiotics worked to save the TEs and the LD flaps healed as well.  My scars look awful but hope he can correct them at exchange. Summergal-BC does affect the whole family, it is as scarey for them as they feel so helpless.  Good coping is to get away from it all for awhile, so giving DH a break will pay off for you tomorrow.  Therapy does help as I have one at the hospital that was my "coach" for my management class.  She has been so great to listen and help me through it all.  My DH is disabled and has so many problems of his own he just is in denial that I have anything going on.  He has had so much of the attention for his issues (stroke, dialysis, diabetes) he just doesn't know how to react.  I quit trying to include him in the office visits after he asked the bs "what did she do to get this?"  My bs asked me if I had a therapist as she worried about depression after surgery.  I told her I had a coach to get me through.   BellaFriday-to have you here, sorry you need to be here!  I will add you to our surgery list.  What a double whammy with a hyst.  I had an endometrial biopsy and will be headed that direction next, yet can wait for now.  GYN wants to give my poor body some time to recover from this first.  I worry about it all the same.  On Tamoxifen which increases the chance for uterine cancer, so want to get it out too.  If bleeding gets worse she will do it sooner.  I do not know much about the nipple sharing surgeries but check out the reconstruction threads, there may be some who do.  I did not have the choice as with LD flap all is taken out plus one of my masses was close to the left nipple.  I will do either nipple recon or tattoos, will have to wait 6 months after exchange, so plenty of time to decide. Denise4603-I am so sorry your hospital stay was so bad. Glad you are doing well.  I am a nurse and realized how much I knew ahead of the nurses what needed to be done.  I was in the hospital 4 days and it was tooo long!  I begged to go home on day 3 but PS wasn't letting me go any earlier due to the LD flap recon.  (front and back incisions and 6 drains)  I was so glad to get home and in my recliner...took me 5 weeks to make it to my bed!  (OMG feeling the PTSD setting in!) KeeB-Hang in there and get rid of the cold first, no need to be sick going into surgery.  Coughing and sneezing would hurt so bad afterward it would not be worth it.  I sneezed my first post op day and thought I would die.  Later I choked on sip of water and it killed me to cough, wanted to just not breathe! LOL! BiG((HUGS)))  for you while you recover.   tuffenough-So glad all turned out so well for you.  I can't imagine going through a wedding after all this!  When my daughter got married I was so exhausted afterward, you are amazing.  Hope you can rest up for returning to work, it is hard to get back into it at first, take it easy. Will update our surgery list and post separately-(my computer is acting up tonight).

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2013 12:29PM mamasixtaz wrote: Hello all hope all are recovering well as we approach the end of the month!  I had a pretty crummy couple of days battling nausea/vomiting/pain issues.  I thought this exchange surgery was to be the easiest, so far not for me.  I don't know why I can't keep anything down.  Called PS yesterday got some zofran and finally kept it down with water and toast.  Then the vicodin was upsetting the balance but due to the vomiting really escalated the pain.  What a rollercoaster ride!  Stopped the vicodin and alternated motrin and tylenol for better tummy and tolerated a little more pain.  Now, the nausea is better tolerating more food but soo tired.  Kicked my butt this time.  I guess I was spoiled in the hospital 4 days last time with people monitoring meds, etc never got nauseated until I got home and it was short lived.  I told the PS that he really beat me up as my arms and chest really hurt.  More sharp stabbing pain noted this time as well.  He thinks it may be some nerve pain as we stirred up those nerves with the exchange.  Not what I had thought it would be like, but just when I think I have it figured out, wham! along comes a surprise!   Glad to have the expanders out and the implants are sooo much softer, yet still very noticeable.  Hope to get use to them over time and once they "fluff and drop" we will see how it goes.  Lefty is half again as big as the righty.  Lots of swelling and underarm boob.  Only time I wished for a drain as I think my pain would be less if not so much fluid trapped.  (We just can't be happy can we, drains or no drains!LOL)  Wishing all a restful and painfree weekend!

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 02:30AM mamasixtaz wrote: Sandymomof3-Welcome to the September surgery board, sorry you had to join us, but here we are...playing the waiting game.  The anxiety around surgery I found to be the worst part of it all.  Our minds play tricks on us making it really weigh us down.  I found to stay busy and keep the mind occupied is the way I cope with the waiting game.  If you exercise or go for walks it helps as well.  Keeping in touch on these boards helps too.  The time passes by quickly when you are busy.  antibigler-It is a hard decision to make.  It is a personal one and once made it is done ,no second guessing.  Hang in there we know what you are going through.  Many have decided to do UMX vs BMX and are very happy with the decision and live a long happy life. hobbesla4-Worry is a curse, but here we are.  The pathology and reports to follow will lead you in different directions, many we don't prefer but life goes on.  Jump through each hoop as it comes and lean on those around you for support.  My BFF is the best.  I could text, call, anytime and cry, laugh, curse whatever to get through the tough times.  I think it was harder for her than me sometimes.  We are like sisters and known each other over 20 years.  We have been through this journey together and I couldn't have done it without her. My story:  I am 54 yrs old mom of 4 with the youngest starting highschool this year!  My DH is disabled, had a stroke 7 yrs ago and in end stage renal failure, on home hemodialysis.  I work full time as an L&D nurse.  Never imagined this could ever happen to me.  My cancer was dx by routine mamo, multiple biopies, lumpectomy x2 unable to get good margins and DCIS along with papillary carcinoma.  BS said too much cancer to get with the lumpectomy, lead me to bmx.  I decided bmx due to micocalcification changes in the right side, not wanting to end up going through this again.  PS decided latissimus dorsi + TEs was the best option for reconstruction.  This was not in my plan as well!  8hrs later and back and front incisions and 6 drains!  But here I am 5 months out a few set backs with incisional infections and slow fills (total 800cc each)  and I am ready to get this finished with 800cc silicone implants! Hope this helps and does not scare you but if I can do it so can all of you.  I am back working full time since May 5th in a busy L&D unit.  It is hard trying to keep up with everything, I get so tired, exhausted but glad to be able to work and take care of my family and each day does get a little easier. Sorry so long...sending you all many anti-anxiety ((HUGS!!))

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2013 01:35AM mamasixtaz wrote: summergal and fiddledee-  Lumpectomies are not "just lumpectomies". They are a great way to conserve the breast you have.  I went through lumpectomy first just to see if we could conserve the breast.  There is nothing like your own body parts.  Nothing replaces them unless you really have to.  No one would consider cutting off a hand or foot without considering it would save your life.  But breast cancer is still not understood to the point that surgery is still the option used first.  After my double lumpectomies my BS was confident that she got good margins on both, but the pathology came back with one with good margins and one not, and that  included DCIS/LCIS.  I still wouldn't have changed anything.  At least I knew that the breast needed to go to prevent any cancer spread.  I decided bmx only to make them match as I had large boobs, and my BFF said, why would you want to have one perky new boob and one 54yr saggy boob!  Plus, I had some microcalcifications on MRI, making me suspect more might be there.  Sure enough the pathology on my right side after mx was ALH/LCIS making it also high risk so I'm glad I did it at the same time. This was my personal decsion making process as we all need to evaluate what we can from good sources like BC.org as well as our personal feelings/emotions.  I would have loved to have kept my real boobs and had careful screenings but, that was not a choice in my case. What a journey and rollercoaster ride it has been since last December when I heard those words " you have breast cancer".  The anxiety and anticipation is the worst part, just hang on and grab support wherever you can.

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2013 04:42AM mamasixtaz wrote: SchoolC-Hang in there...it does seem like a long journey, but it is one stage at a time.  Before bc I never even considered cosmetic surgery even though many of my co-workers have had implants.  That is a whole different surgery. Adding an implant is not the same as replacing what we had.  No one wants this bc but here we are and we make the best choices based on the information we have available.  In the end we have to trust our instincts and our care providers to take the cancer out and make us still feel good about our body.  I was in your place in March.  It seems like such a long time ago now.  I had no idea what to expect, who to trust and if I would be able to support and take care of my family.  It was a dark time but I made it through it and so will you.  BMX with TEs does take time.  You need time to heal and make the area ready for the implants.  It depends on the PS on how soon they will do the exchange after the last fill.  But slow and steady wins the race and it will pass quickly (some days good, some days bad)  I understand and feel for you tonight so hang in there tomorrow will be here soon, and a day closer to the end of the journey! Many many ((HUGGGGGGS))!!

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2013 03:49AM mamasixtaz wrote: SchoolC-These days will come and go, bad, black ,cloudy and thunderstorm days.  We all have them and move on.  The anticipation for our surgeries is still the worst.  Once the day is here and behind you the recovery can begin.  It is still a fight but you keep on going and make it through.  Lean on all your support around you.  Family, friends, counselors, therapists,  pastors are all around you and now is the time to use them. Keeping busy always helps me, cleaning, cooking, knitting, and shopping, as well as my job.  All are great distractions that keep the mind from dwelling on what is to come.   peacestrength-Keep on hanging in there the recovery will start getting better.  The worst was the first couple of weeks then it began to feel better each day.  It was March when I had my bmx/LD recon and it snowed about every other day, really was hard to get out. Had some really bad cabin fever staying in most of the time.  Some of my co-workers took me to  my  post op appt and treated me to a great lunch.  It was sooo good to get out even with the snow and ice, and drains!  We make it through this and do become a little stronger.   hobbesla4-This cancer journey is riddled with detours!  Never in my dreams did I ever think when I heard those words"you have breast cancer" that I would end up here waiting again on my 3rd surgery this year.  There are many tests and biopsies that are done and most turn out there is nothing.  Hoping yours will be nothing too, but if not we will be here for you to help you through the next turn in the road of bc. Yogagal-yea for your neg BRCA! Your surgery is just before mine, wishing you the best getting through the lx. Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2013 02:51AM mamasixtaz wrote: vivian-I had some PT prior to exchange, to help strengthen by arms and back. The physical therapist said she had worked with mastectomy patients, even LD flap patients, but some of the exercises were for strengthening the LD muscle, which didn't make sense to me as it was moved to the front and needs to atrophy. I didn't go back. I talked to BS and PS about possible LE in my underarm and trunk area and both really downplayed it saying I was such a low risk for LE and my arm would swell up if it was LE. Very hard to convince doctors who think they know about it. I have thought about going outside my insurance and check out some private PT/LE specialists in my area. I also know many of the nurses in my insurance who can help me find out who may be available within my plan. I am sure I can get my PS to refer me to one if I do the homework! I think it would help as well. Just negotiating the system is the hard part!

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2013 09:47PM mamasixtaz wrote: cjc-I have had this since bmx, but I also had LD flap reconstruction, which brings the muscle under my arm to the front. My right side seems back to normal post exchange, but I have some fluid that just hasn't moved since exchange on my left side (cancer/SN side). After bmx, I had my drains 4 weeks then weekly had seroma removed from my back for another 3 weeks post drain removal. So, not too concerned about the extra fluid build up, but it is uncomfortable, especially without a sport bra. Have an appt Friday to see LE specialist, help with moving the fluid out on that left side. I was surprised at how much this surgery has wiped me out! I had less general anesthesia this time but was sent home the same day,(last time 8hrs surgery, 4 days in hospital) which I thought would be better. But, I had less help around and was so sick from the pain meds I just didn't bounce back as fast as I thought I would. I did seem to feel like I had been run over by a truck and beat up with a baseball bat! My arms were sore and hard to move again as well. But, after the first few days things started to feel better, quicker than my bmx surgery. Most people do really well after exchange surgery and return to "normal". But if you check out the Exchange thread, there are those who have trouble with healing, final results, etc just like bmx recoveries are not all the same. Some have more surgery for revisions, exchange is not always the final surgery. I am hoping it is MY last surgery!

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2013 04:06AM mamasixtaz wrote: Hello all, been off the boards for awhile, just catching up on the many posts. Sounds like all are doing well and improving each day! I have only a week left off before heading back to work. 6 weeks can go so quickly! I am doing better each day post exchange. The foobs are healing nicely and my swelling is pretty much gone in the breast. Still some underarm boob, but LE specialist is working wonders in moving the fluid out with exercises and massage. I did go shopping looking for new bras, as the sports bras are so worn out since I have been wearing them since bmx, with expansion thru now. I loved my bali revolution sport bras as they had some definition and wide sides for my underarm boob support. But, I am about ready to get sized by a professional, (Nordstroms) and buy something nice for work. Be interesting to see what size I am now. Plus with the weight loss have needed to buy some clothes, dropped 3 sizes in jeans! Still continuing to loose, may be from the Tamoxifen. Try to get outside everyday and walk, averaging about 1-2 miles. The fall weather has been extraordinary! Hoping all of your surgeries are healing well, and the fills will move along quickly, the exchange to squishies is the easiest so far. I think about all of you often and read the posts when I can. Many ((HUGS)) to all!

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2013 02:39AM mamasixtaz wrote: Yea for September 3rd!  So glad to hear from some of our surgery sisters and most are doing well. DawnCT and Hobbesla4- I agree the wire insertion was the worst for me during the lumpectomy.  I too had 2 wires inserted but did have them stop and add more anesthestic/local.  It made it much more tolerable.  Had to resquish the breast but it was worth it.  Does seem like a vice holding it down tight.  Then it's the adjustments to the wires they have to make while it  is being squished!  I remember there was a pink beany bear with the pink ribbon symbol on a shelf across from the machine where I was looking.  I wanted to rip that bear's head off by the time I was done!  (I'm not a pink ribbon fan, just can't deal with that yet!) Then they covered the wires with syringes and I had to go up a public elevator to the surgery center!  Not a pretty sight!  I also had the SNB isotopes injected which wasn't pleasant either, a big needlestick in an area that is the most sensitive on your body (the nipple area). I think the surgery was the easier part, but who knows at least you get to sleep through that! LOL!  Glad you are done, hope the wait on results isn't too long.  Rest up and take it easy, you still had surgery so take time to recover. I too had an endometrial biopsy in the GYN office today, ouch some cramping but better now.  Needed this as a baseline to monitor for uterine cancer which is a risk with Tamoxifen. It is just another part of this journey.  Will get the results just as in about 7 days.  I know it will probably be benign (no hx) but I never thought I'd have bc either(no hx).  Many gentle virtual ((HUGS)) to all. Good luck tomorrow, Dennilynne, we will be thinking of you!  Get some rest as much as you can, the anticipation is the worst!

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2013 06:03AM mamasixtaz wrote: Hi all, tired so a quick note to check in...welcome Lee1963;Sorry you had to join us but here we are ready to help each other. Summergal was right in her post, check in with your BS to see if you will need wire loc and if the SNB isotopes are done ahead of surgery, most are as it takes awhile to absorb and go to the nodes. Wishing you well, hang in there one day at a time. BellaFriday-everyone is different on pain meds needed post op, but you need them for at least 3 + days. Take stoolsoftners 2X a day and milk of mag too if needed. Fiber bars help too. Move things down to lower cabinets, no reaching. You feel like "T-Rex" short arms move close to your body. I also had LDFlap recon so had back incisons as well, you should do fine with umx, and TE. Each surgeon uses different bras,etc. Mine used nothing but dressings, no surgical bras or anything for a month. Use only sport bras now, helps support my underarm boob, swelling left from tunneling of LD muscle, check with your PS what they use. Front button tops help to get dressed too, jacket with inside pockets to hold your drains is good too. Music, DVDS, and pillows to prop your arms( I like the small travel pillows from Walmart, only $3! Good for car rides to post op for seat belts,etc. Finally, nap,sleep,rest,rest,sleep some more, heal...hope this helps, big(((HUGS))! I will be right behind you on the surgery list.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 08:50PM mamasixtaz wrote: SchoolC-Sorry to hear you are having so much pain.  Try to  keep up on the pain meds (don't forget the stool softners/lax as it is a whole other problem!).  It just takes time but slowly it will feel better. You can add the muscle relaxers too.  They didn't help much until I had my fills, then they were great.  Norco and motrin was the best for  me during my surgical pain.  I think it was several weeks before I came off of the meds round the clock and then several more weeks taking them at night.  I did have the added bonus incisions on my back to deal with as well, with 6 drains!  I was soooo swollen under my arms from the tunneling of the LD muscle and I tried ice. I called the PS nurse to ask for more meds and told her I was using ice, OMG she was soo upset, you can get a ice burn due to you have decreased sensation.  Yep, I did then broke out in hives around the drains under my arm.  I was a mess, hives, infection, necrosis  and a lot of family issues to deal with on top of it.  I made it through it and so can you!  Keep hanging in there and really rest, rest, rest.  It is the hardest thing for most of us to do.  I am going to do better this time! LOL!  Sooo much more ready for this surgery, and I know it will be a better recovery from all who have gone before.  The light is at the end of the tunnel, (yea it is not a train!).   Hope all are recovering well and feeling better each day!  Go Broncos!

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2013 12:05AM mamasixtaz wrote: Wow what a discussion board, its been busy, took me awhile to get caught up! Welcome all (jhawk and Jo) who have just joined and hello to all who are now recovering! BellaF-I feel your pain with the TEs. Mine were filled to 500cc at surgery and added up to 800cc at final fill. My PS won't exchange till 12 weeks after last fill, so yes they were sooo tight and uncomfortable. I did get used to it some but never was able to sleep other than on my back. It was very tiring and I did take the muscle relaxers especially at night. It is all worth it after exchange. So, hang in there, the implants are sooo much better, I can sleep on my side, finally! You will have that tightness and "iron bra" feeling till they are exchanged. Mine is still there some even since the exchange, but it is so much less. When you go for the fill be sure and tell PS how uncomfortable you are and start slow. Ask how much he plans to fill you to and how much each fill will be. You drive the amount of fills, take it easy as many PSs start at 100ccs and it is reallly too much. As uncomfortable you are be sure and take meds before you go in for the fill and routinely after. Get muscle relaxers, they do help.

Just need to make sure I am doing the "right" exercise. cjc/batrice-underarm boob is what still bothers me the most. (I am 6 months out) I blamed the LD flap surgery but it must be related to mx as well. My right side has gone down but still swells some. My left(cancer side) is still the worst. I have had seroma drained from my back post mx but PS won't take off any more. Take it easy and let things heal and the fluid will not build up as much and the swelling/pain will go down. BellaF-Yea, drains out! Slow and steady wins the race! (slow fills weekly) TEs are just not comfortable but it does become more tolerable over time. My BFF was always there for me when I was so uncomfortable from the fills. One day she said, well it's like puberty all over again, growing new boobs! Don't become too attached they are only place holders the squishy side is sooo much better!

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 02:42AM mamasixtaz wrote: Beatrice-Constipation is such a problem with surgery and the related pain meds. I took stool softners the combo of two drugs and milk of mag(MOM) when unable to keep going with the stool softners. I would take 2 in AM and 2 in PM and then MOM in the PM again until I was off the narcotics. I started the day before this surgery with stool softners and didn't need any MOM this time. Was off the narcotics after only 2 days. Hope you find a balance for your body soon. SchoolC-Good for you in getting a second opinion, it can't hurt to check it out. Sandra-I guess we will never have a 0% of recurrance, yet we do what we needed to do to make it as little as possible. My MO was so good at explaining that yes there is still breast tissue there and with routine exams by our Drs we can be watched for any recurrance. I know I worry some about it but know I have done what I can, the rest is in God's hands. I take my Tamoxifen each day and hope with all the hot flashes/night sweats that it is doing its job to keep cancer away. SiennaS-welcome to our forum, glad you posted with us. I feel your pain as it is such a similar story to mine. I too was dx with left side IDC but MRI showed more areas of concern. Double lumpectomy done and not clear margins lead me down the path of bmx, LD flap recon. Did you get implants immediately? I wasn't able to do immediate implants but did TEs and LD flap. If you were able to get it all done, great! You will not need to have additional surgery for the implants! I had 6 drains but know each surgeon is different. Hope you are feeling better soon, and get those drains out too. Katlebbie-Thanks for your prayers and concern. The swelling goes down some during the night then comes right back by the end of the day. I am going to call BS nurse for referral for LE specialist on Monday. It can't hurt to try some massage and exercises to get this to move the fluid out and "drain" better.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2013 05:32PM mamasixtaz wrote: cjc-I had my bmx/LD flap recon 5 weeks post lumpectomies and my tissue was just not healed well from the lumpectomies and the incisions were near the area where my PS put the LD flap.  So, infection first set in(even on antibiotics IV and oral) and then an area about the size of a quarter on the upper side of my flap started to turn black, necrose.  He went in and excised the area and all the top portion of the infected incisions (both left and right) and gave me multiple antibiotics about 14 days post surgery and it did clear up after that.  The incision looked very angry (pink and wide) but at exchange he took care of it again and so far looks great! My TEs and flap were saved but it was touch and go for a couple of weeks till healing finally won out.  This is why when people tell us about fevers, reddness, drainage, those of us who have been there know to act fast.  It is what I think saved my TE and LD flap.  These are complications of surgery and most do not experience them, but it is good to know and be aware of your own body and what you are seeing and feeling.  It is better to overreact than be sorry later. Hope you can make it through the next couple of days knowing it will all be over soon, you will do fine and be in recovery mode soon. sandra-Even after the exchange surgery my ribs and sternum really hurt afterward.  Not as bad as BMX but was more painful than I expected.  I asked PS if he used a baseball bat to beat my chest up, he paused and thought a bit and said no he decided to leave it at home! I guess it is all the muscle manipulation in taking out the TEs and putting in the implants.  He did do ''quite a bit of pocket work" he said.  I have some bruising as well but not too much this time.  Still lots of swelling and underarm boob.  Hope all goes down soon.  It does take the body time to heal, some of us more than others...more of that waiting that I really really hate!  Ready to get on with my life after cancer, it is sooo close.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2013 12:32AM mamasixtaz wrote: SchoolC-Ask your MO about Oncotype DX, it is a good tool to dx those of us with DCIS and stage 1 need for chemo.  The score is reliable in dx recurrance, many have used it on previous threads.  My MO suggested it but when my nodes were clear and I decided on bmx after my lumpectomy my MO said it wasn't necessary.  But, as we have said before all Drs are different in their approaches.  But, doesn't hurt to ask! Pain meds--narcotics yuk!  I had to take them last time and also this time, but they just make me sick, literally!  Was so glad to get off of them and on to motrin and tylenol.  Alternating every 3 hrs works well for me and decreases the pukes!  Beatrice-T-REX!  The only way to describe it! With exchange it returns to a degree, only a shorter time.  That surprised me, never thought it would be back after exchange.  Keep those pillows handy!  Glad you are on the recovery train! My swelling on the lefty continues, saw my PS yesterday and he admits I probably need a drain. Seroma returns! No aspiration near gel implants!  So, if not getting better we may need to return to surgery and  put in a drain.  My incisions look soo good, don't want to disturb them again, let alone, anesthesia, pain and more puking!  He gave me the choice now or wait a week and see if the swelling goes down on its own.  Sports bras help compress them enough to relieve the pressure.  The squishies are sooo much better even with the seroma pressure I think I can wait it out.  My underarm is like a roll of pillsbury cookie dough, so proping up my arms when I sit for comfort as well.  Feels like more fluid is building up in by back as well, but PS didn't really feel any, as he could remove it back there, just not near the breast area.  Just never ends!  Otherwise each day is getting better, just no energy, or appetite.  Will take it one day at a time!  Thinking of everyone and hope the recoveries are going well for all! Many ((HUGS))!!

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2013 02:57AM mamasixtaz wrote: Wow what a busy board. Hard to keep up but life is keeping me busy, yea life after cancer and surgery! Still having swelling in the left, sports bra helps not as painful during the day, notice it more at night. Probably doing too much too, as I am feeling better and better. Hard not to try and get some things done around the house before the snow flies. Our weather has been great (70s) can't stay inside with it like this! Decorating for Halloween, it is so much fun with all the kids in the neighborhood, even though mine are 14-29! Glad for the good news on all of your results and advancing surgery dates. I will see LE specialist next week, takes awhile to get in but hope they can help move some of this fluid out. Otherwise I love my new squishies.(almost 2 weeks!) I feel for you who are going through the TE torture. I hated mine so much but once the fills are done you do learn to tolerate them, so hang in there it will get better. Take the pain meds and be good to yourself, this time will pass and your exchange will be here. My implants are 800cc Mentor high profile plus gels. It is hard to say what size I will be as they still need to settle or " drop and fluff". In the exchange forum, discussions on how they change over the next 3-6 months is another process. Now my left is swollen and the right is pretty normal now, so I think I will be a small D, which is good with me. They look very natural not hard like the TEs that were sticking up to my colarbone! Now they are where they should be maybe a little flatter in clothes. I have lost almost 50lbs in the last 6 months (which I had to loose) so my clothes hang on me anyway! I told my family to get me clothes for Christmas! By then I will know the size and be fitted for some new bras! I am happy with the results so far. Thinking of all who have had surgery and the struggles and anxiety you face. I have been there and understand. Still have my good days and bad but hopefully more good days ahead. Many many warm (((HUGS!!!)) to all.

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2013 10:23PM mamasixtaz wrote: tparksprof-In breast reconstruction TEs are tissue expanders used to expand the tissue and muscle to make a pocket for the final implant.  DIEP is also a reconstruction procedure using tissue from the abdomen to make new foobs, not needing implants made of silicone or saline.  I had Latissimus Dorsi muscle moved from my back to the front with tissue expanders.  Once gradually filled to the size we need the tissue expanders are removed and replaced by implants made of silicone.  There are so many reconstruction options now available to those who choose reconstruction.   Sounds like you are healing well and feeling better.   My infection is clear and incisions healing well enough to expand my tissue expanders.  Ready to move on in this process to getting my permanent implants!
